misconceptions.name: Complete Misunderstanding of Task Requirements
misconceptions.description: The student implemented a program to calculate average acceleration (a physics formula) based on three double inputs (V0, V1, T) instead of writing the required program to read five integers and sum the even ones.
misconceptions.student_belief: This submission correctly addresses the requirements of the assignment.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The assignment requires reading exactly 5 integer inputs, using a conditional structure (if) and modulo operator (%) to check for even numbers, and using an accumulator variable to compute the sum.
symptoms: Code takes 3 double inputs instead of 5 integer inputs
Code calculates acceleration A = (V1 - V0) / T
No loops or conditional checks related to evenness are present
misconceptions.root_cause: Major misinterpretation of the requested problem/submitting code from a completely different assignment.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Please review the problem description carefully. The goal is to process multiple inputs (using a loop) and filter them using a conditional statement based on evenness.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The supplied code performs a calculation entirely unrelated to the prompt (acceleration calculation versus sum of even numbers).

evidence.note: The inputs read and the calculation performed are for average acceleration, not for summing even numbers.

misconceptions.name: Completely Wrong Problem Solution
misconceptions.description: Student submitted code that solves a different problem entirely (acceleration calculation) instead of the assigned problem (sum of even numbers). This indicates either a copy-paste error, submission of wrong file, or fundamental misunderstanding of the assignment.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe this code solves the sum of even numbers problem, or submitted the wrong file entirely.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The assigned task is to read 5 integers and sum only the even ones. The submitted code reads 3 doubles and calculates acceleration using the formula A = (V1 - V0) / T, which is completely unrelated.
symptoms: Code solves physics acceleration problem instead of even number summation
Reads 3 doubles instead of 5 integers
Uses wrong input prompt and output message
No loop structure present
No even number checking logic
Output doesn't match expected sample run
misconceptions.root_cause: Student submitted code for a different problem, suggesting either accidental file submission, copy-paste error from wrong assignment, or fundamental confusion about the assignment requirements.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the problem statement carefully. The task is to read 5 integers, check each one to see if it's even (using n % 2 == 0), and sum only the even numbers. Use a loop (for or while) to process all 5 inputs.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Extremely high confidence. The submitted code is objectively solving a different problem (physics acceleration) with different input types, different number of inputs, and different logic. This is not a misconception about the assigned problem but rather submission of entirely wrong code.

evidence.note: This code calculates acceleration from velocity and time, not sum of even numbers. Wrong problem entirely.
Reads 3 doubles instead of 5 integers as required by problem.

misconceptions.name: Solved a different physics problem instead of the specified task
misconceptions.description: The program computes average acceleration from v0, v1, and t instead of reading 5 integers and summing the even ones as required by the assignment.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student believes the task is to calculate average acceleration given initial velocity, final velocity, and time.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The task is to read exactly 5 integers from the user, identify which of them are even (n % 2 == 0), sum only those even numbers, and print the sum.
symptoms: Prompt asks for v0, v1, and t instead of 5 integers
Only three values are read from input
No loop or conditional logic related to even numbers
Output text refers to average acceleration, not sum of even numbers
misconceptions.root_cause: Confusion about or misreading of the problem statement, possibly copying a solution to a different textbook exercise.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the problem statement carefully and rewrite the program so it reads 5 integers, checks each for evenness using n % 2 == 0, accumulates a running sum of the even ones, and prints that sum.
related_concepts: Reading and translating specifications into code
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: All variable names, prompt text, and formula clearly match an average-acceleration exercise, with no elements related to summing even numbers.

evidence.note: Prompt, variables, and formula all implement an average acceleration calculation rather than summing even numbers.

misconceptions.name: Using double input where integers are required
misconceptions.description: The student declares the input variables as double and uses nextDouble() even though the assignment specifies reading integers.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student believes it's appropriate to read these values as doubles for this task.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: When a problem specifies integers, the corresponding Java variables should typically be of type int (and read using nextInt()), unless there is a specific reason to use a floating-point type.
symptoms: Input variables typed as double instead of int
Scanner uses nextDouble() methods
misconceptions.root_cause: Overgeneralization of using double for numeric values or copying from a physics example where real-valued input is expected.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Change the variable types to int and use INPUT.nextInt() when the problem specifies integer input, unless fractional values are explicitly needed.
related_concepts: Choosing appropriate data types for problem requirements
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The problem explicitly requires integers, while the code consistently uses double and nextDouble() for all inputs.

evidence.note: All inputs are read as double using nextDouble(), conflicting with the requirement to read integers.

misconceptions.name: Solved an unrelated problem (Physics formula)
misconceptions.description: The student implemented logic to calculate average acceleration (A = (V1 - V0) / T), suggesting they misunderstood the assignment prompt completely or submitted code for a different question. The implemented code reads 3 doubles instead of 5 integers and performs an acceleration calculation, not a sum filtering operation.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student believes the assigned task was to calculate average acceleration given initial velocity (V0), final velocity (V1), and time (T).
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The assignment required reading 5 integers and calculating the sum of the even numbers among them.
symptoms: Program input consists of three doubles, not five integers.
Program output is 'The average acceleration is ...', not 'Sum of even numbers: ...'.
The core logic involves subtraction and division, not modulo operations or accumulation.
misconceptions.root_cause: Misreading the prompt, submitting the wrong file, or confusion about which problem needs to be solved.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Please review the assignment prompt carefully and implement the required logic: reading five numbers, checking for evenness, and accumulating the sum.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The entire provided code implements a physics formula calculation that has no relationship whatsoever to the stated problem (Sum of Even Numbers).

evidence.note: The code implements the calculation for average acceleration, not the sum of even numbers.

misconceptions.name: Incorrect use of data type (using double instead of integer)
misconceptions.description: The problem requires reading integers, but the student used `nextDouble()` to read floating-point values (doubles).
misconceptions.student_belief: Inputs specified in the problem definition can be read using `nextDouble()` regardless of whether they are described as integers.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: To read an integer input, `nextInt()` should be used, and the corresponding variable should be of type `int`.
symptoms: Used `nextDouble()` three times instead of `nextInt()` five times.
misconceptions.root_cause: Lack of attention to the required data type or not knowing the difference between `nextDouble()` and `nextInt()` for input scanning.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Ensure you use the correct Scanner method (`nextInt()`) when expecting integer inputs.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code explicitly calls `nextDouble()` for variables V0, V1, and T, which contradicts the problem requirement of reading 5 integers.

evidence.note: Used double for variables and nextDouble() for input, when integers were required.

misconceptions.name: Wrong problem solved - physics calculation instead of integer summing
misconceptions.description: The student has submitted code that solves a different problem entirely. The code reads 3 doubles and calculates average acceleration (a = (v1-v0)/t) instead of reading 5 integers and summing the even numbers.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe they are solving a physics/kinematics problem involving velocity and acceleration calculations.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: This assignment requires reading 5 integers, filtering for even numbers using the modulo operator (n % 2 == 0), and printing their sum.
symptoms: Code calculates acceleration instead of summing evens
Reads 3 doubles instead of 5 integers
Prints completely different output than required
No loop, no accumulator, no even/odd logic present
misconceptions.root_cause: Student submitted code for the wrong problem or did not read the assignment specification carefully.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Reread the problem statement carefully. The assignment requires: (1) a loop to read 5 integers, (2) a conditional to check if each number is even (n % 2 == 0), (3) an accumulator to sum even numbers, and (4) output of the sum.
related_concepts: The modulo operator (%) for remainder calculation
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Very high confidence: the submitted code is completely unrelated to the assigned problem. It solves an acceleration problem rather than an even-sum problem.

evidence.note: Code reads 3 doubles and calculates acceleration; problem requires reading 5 integers and summing evens.
